docs.abstract: Louis C.K. reminded the “Late Show” host that before he was the “king of the late-night” shows, he was just a quirky guy.
docs.snippet: Louis C.K. reminded the “Late Show” host that before he was the “king of the late-night” shows, he was just a quirky guy.
docs.lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. What do you think of it? What else are you interested in? Let us know: thearts@nytimes.com.

headline.main: Stephen Colbert Was ‘Like an Alien’ Before He Was Famous, Louis C.K. Says

docs.abstract: James Forman Jr.’s “Locking Up Our Own” and Chris Hayes’s “A Colony in a Nation” compel readers to wrestle with very tough questions about racism, inequality and punishment.
docs.snippet: James Forman Jr.’s “Locking Up Our Own” and Chris Hayes’s “A Colony in a Nation” compel readers to wrestle with very tough questions about racism, inequality and punishment.
docs.lead_paragraph: (“Locking Up Our Own: Crime and Punishment in Black America” by James Forman Jr. was selected as one of The New York Times Book Review’s 10 Best Books of 2017. For the rest of the list, click here.)

headline.main: Power and Punishment: Two New Books About Race and Crime

keywords.name: creative_works
keywords.value: Locking Up Our Own: Crime and Punishment in Black America (Book)

docs.abstract: “You’re so lucky,” my son said to me. “People look at you and know that you are black.”
docs.snippet: “You’re so lucky,” my son said to me. “People look at you and know that you are black.”
docs.lead_paragraph: My 11-year-old is understated, but not shy. He likes to bake, loves video games, is loyal to his friends and, biased as I may be, is a pretty good-looking kid. He gets mad sometimes, though, that people don’t immediately register him as black. “You’re so lucky,” he said to me a few months ago. “People look at you and know that you are black.”

headline.main: Black and Proud. Even if Strangers Can’t Tell.

docs.abstract: The artist Awol Erizku is opening his first solo show in Europe with his most political work to date.
docs.snippet: The artist Awol Erizku is opening his first solo show in Europe with his most political work to date.
docs.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — By one measure of success, the 28-year-old artist Awol Erizku has possibly already peaked. In February he was revealed to be the photographer behind Beyoncé’s pregnancy announcement, which quickly became the most popular Instagram post ever with over 10 million likes.

headline.main: Beyoncé’s Pregnancy Photographer Is Opening an ‘Anti-Trump’ Art Show

docs.abstract: Our roundup of the news and feature stories about young people that have recently appeared across sections of NYTimes.com.
docs.snippet: Our roundup of the news and feature stories about young people that have recently appeared across sections of NYTimes.com.
docs.lead_paragraph: Welcome to the March 2017 edition of Teenagers in The Times, our monthly roundup of the news and feature stories about young people that have recently appeared across sections of NYTimes.com. You can find our next installment on May 5.

docs.abstract: It’s no surprise that co-opting a cause for marketing went terribly wrong.
docs.snippet: It’s no surprise that co-opting a cause for marketing went terribly wrong.
docs.lead_paragraph: Pepsi on Wednesday pulled a disastrous advertisement after it was met with widespread ridicule. Titled “Jump In,” the two-and-a-half minute spot was full of clumsy, glib references to police brutality and Black Lives Matter protests. Nearly every tone-deaf frame has become a mocking meme. And the commercial (Pepsi calls it a “short film”) drew the most intense disgust from the very people whose experiences it tried to reflect.

headline.main: A Pepsi Commercial’s Lesson for Advertisers

docs.abstract: In 1997, the Justice Department entered its first consent decree, with the Pittsburgh police. Nineteen cities later, it has learned from its mistakes.
docs.snippet: In 1997, the Justice Department entered its first consent decree, with the Pittsburgh police. Nineteen cities later, it has learned from its mistakes.
docs.lead_paragraph: PITTSBURGH — Federal intervention to curb police abuse did not begin after chants of “I can’t breathe,” viral cellphone videos or the Black Lives Matter movement.

headline.main: ‘It Did Not Stick’: The First Federal Effort to Curb Police Abuse
headline.print_headline: The Rise and Fall of Federal Efforts to Curb Police Abuse

docs.abstract: Carol H. Williams, who was behind major campaigns for Pillsbury, Secret and Disney, will be only the second black woman in the Advertising Hall of Fame.
docs.snippet: Carol H. Williams, who was behind major campaigns for Pillsbury, Secret and Disney, will be only the second black woman in the Advertising Hall of Fame.
docs.lead_paragraph: Carol H. Williams started working in the advertising business in 1969, when young African-American women like her were a rarity in the industry.

headline.main: An Ad Woman at the Top of an Industry That She Thinks Still Has Far to Go
headline.print_headline: An Ad Woman at the Top of an Industry That She Thinks Still Has Far to Go

docs.abstract: Outside the classroom, we inhabit the same world.
docs.snippet: Outside the classroom, we inhabit the same world.
docs.lead_paragraph: For black students, having even one black teacher can make a huge difference. That’s the conclusion of a new study, which found that that black boys who had a black teacher during their elementary school years were less likely to drop out of high school. It also linked the presence of black teachers to kids’ expectations of attending college.

headline.main: The Real Reason Black Kids Benefit From Black Teachers
